Description: Copper alloy roughly made amuletic figure of a deity with human body, wearing the shendit-kilt, standing on a narrow and flat rectangular base, in walking posture, left leg forward, and arms alongside the body. The head has a lion or ram (if not human ?) face with an undetermined headdress, possibly a solar disc with an uraeus. The amulet has a vertical suspension ring behind the headdress above what might be an uraeus protruding from the back of the figure.
Curator's comments: Possibly one of the bronze figures of deities mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 80 § 80 ?
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 80 § 80) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.62, p.180, pl.22)
